content.description: Big Air is located on the right arete of the west face. Sit start on the arete. Powerful moves lead to better holds off the deck. It is probably V5 by modern standards.
content.location: The right arete on the west face.

content.description: This problem is located to the right of "little air" on the backside of the Air Jordan Boulder.  From a stand start on crimps step up to an intermediate crimp and deadpoint the to lip.  I found a toe scum useful.  Ok for another warmup.
content.location: Located on the backside of the Air Jordan Boulder.

content.description: The crux is in your head, a fall from the wrong spot on this problem could definitely break a leg. Thin climbing on the arete, small edges and knobs.
content.location:
This is the arete right of

Into Thin Air

starting off the 5' tall boulder at the end of the face.

content.description: When sent this will be one of the hardest and best lines at Sheep Nose. I know several individuals who have made it about half way up the face to a point a little to the right of the shallow scoop where it appears you have to make a huge move up and left to a sidepull and somehow use it.
content.protection: Pads, or alternatly there is a bolt on top.
content.location:
Right of

Into Thin Air

and left of

Scarry

, steep shallow scoop.

content.description: Very balancy and odd problem, the crux is probably the one handed deadpoint to the good edge just below the lip with your right hand. Start by getting onto the rail using a very thing right hand undercling and something jizzy for your left, then inch your feet as far right as you can, make the onehanded move and cross to the top.
content.location: To the left of the blunt arete being called the middle problem is a slabby rock to hangout on and on the Air Jordan Boulder is a sloppy rail about 4' up, stand onto this and climb the face.

content.description: This is the downclimb but a makes a good little problem in its own. Nice rounded edges.
content.location: The back side of the boulder, center of the face.

content.description:
This is the problem that is being referred to as the middle problem in the photos. The crux is a committing deadpoint/jump near the top. Some say it's better than

Big Air

, but

Big Air

was the first problem on the boulder.
content.location: Left blunt arete of the west face.

content.description:
Great technical face climbing, good flexability in the legs can make this problem easier.

Movement is pretty continuous, but the most committing move is the pop for the top off of a left hand sidepull/undercling and a very sharp right handed crimp that can be difficult to see, reach right up to an edge a little below the lip and go again to the top.
content.location:
Just right of

Big Air

is a low flared seam then a higher finger crack. SDS in the flare and climb the beautiful slightly overhanging face. V6 from the stand start with the leftt hand in the finger crack used with the right hand on

Big Air

.

content.description: Climb the scooped out section of the face. Pressing up into some underclings then moving out to slopers above. Crux is matching the undercling and moving out of it.

pathTokens: Sleeping Rock aka Sheep's Nose Bouldering
